06/02/2026 - Update des Entwurfs/Version 1- pko

text.text:
BRIDGE Proof of Concept Survey

Welcome to the BRIDGE Proof of Concept end-of-project questionnaire !

Notes
- Filling in the questionnaire takes approx. 15 minutes.
- You can interrupt the survey at any time and resume it later. Click on the "Save interview" button to have your information saved before you interrupt the questionnaire.
- You can scroll back and forth as you wish.

Deadline
Please complete the questionnaire as soon as possible but latest by {{member.DatumE}}.

Contact
If you have any questions, please contact Christian Brunner, Head of BRIDGE (christian.brunner@bridge.ch) or Adrian Berwert, Head of impact analysis, Innosuisse (adrian.berwert@innosuisse.ch).

Thank you for your valuable cooperation!
Information from application / Identification
Title of BRIDGE Proof of Concept project (as in application)
Continue and further develop my current role in academia
Transition from academia to the public sector
Transition from academia to a non-profit / NGO context
Explore new career options without a fixed plan
At the start of the BRIDGE Proof of Concept project, what was your intended career or professional direction?
Founder / co-founder of a start-up or company
Employed in a start-up or young company
Employed in an established company (industry / SME / corporate group)
Employed in a non-profit / NGO organisation
Employed in academia or a research institution
Foreseeable future situation (in the next 12 to 24 months
Which of the following professional situations currently applies to you?
Foreseeable future situation (in the next 12 to 24 months
To what extent is your current or future professional situation related to the BRIDGE Proof of Concept project?

hintText.text: This refers to changes in your own career or professional role, not organisational team changes

sections.name: Characteristics of your BRIDGE Proof of Concept project

text.text: Characteristics of your BRIDGE Proof of Concept project
What type of innovation is the supported project?
economic, social science or humanities basics
Is the innovation from your supported project primarily based on ...

Innovation can be incremental or radical in nature.
Please indicate which applies to the innovation you pursued with your
BRIDGE Proof of Concept project.

hintText.text:
Incremental innovations are further developments and optimisations of existing products, services, processes, business models, etc.

Radical innovations, on the other hand, involve fundamental innovations and changes based on revolutionary ideas or technologies. They can affect products, services, processes, business models or the organisation of the company.

text.text: To what extent does the business idea/innovation of your BRIDGE Proof of Concept project have a disruptive market potential?

hintText.text: Disruptive innovations create completely new markets with new rules of the game and new target groups, and/or succeed in pushing previously successful organisations or existing technologies and applications from the market with innovative products, services, processes or business models.

text.text: Does the BRIDGE Proof of Concept project lead to environmentally and/or social sustainable solutions?

hintText.text:
Environmental sustainability includes e.g. contributions regarding:Social sustainability includes e.g. contributions regarding:
- Climate mitigation and adaptation
- Renewable energy and energy efficiency
- Sustainable mobility
- Sustainable production and consumption, circular economy
- Prevention of environmental pollution (waste, air, water)
- Sustainable use of resources (raw materials, other materials)
- Sustainable water management
- Biodiversity and restoration of habitats (land and water)
- Sustainable design of settlements and cities
- Creation of environmental benefits / reduction of environmental costs
- Social cohesion (expanding soft and hard (public) infrastructure) 
- Reducing gender and other inequalities in the population 
- Social coexistence and participation 
- Quality education - Combating poverty 
- Development promotion and cooperation 
- Creation of social benefits / reduction of social costs

text.text: Please describe the contribution to environmental sustainability in a few sentences:
Please describe the contribution to social sustainability in a few sentences:
To what extent did your BRIDGE Proof of Conept project focus on the development of digital technologies and / or digital business models?

hintText.text:
Examples of digital business modelsExamples of digital technologies
- Software as a Service SaaS / Platform as a Service PaaS 
- Infrastructure as a Service 
- E-Commerce, Marketplace 
- Digital Service Provider (On-Demand, Subscription, Freemium, etc.) 
- Crowdsourcing and Crowdfunding 
- Big Data business model
- Cloud Computing, Cloud sourcing
- Virtual Reality, Augmented Reality
- Virtual Factory, Digital Twin
- Internet of Things (IoT)
- Artificial Intelligence (AI), Deep Learning, Machine Learning, Neural Networks
- Robotics
- Distributed Ledger Technologies (e.g. Blockchain)
- Quantum Computing

text.text: Multi-disciplinary: Participation of different scientific fields or disciplines with specific knowledge and perspectives, each drawing on their disciplinary knowledge to contribute to the solution of the research problem

Inter-disciplinary: Collaboration of different scientific fields or disciplines to jointly find solutions or achieve results by integrating knowledge and methods from different disciplines, using a real synthesis of approaches

Trans-disciplinary: Collaboration from different scientific disciplines with additional participation of actors outside science (e.g. politics, society or other organisations or groups) to develop new ways of thinking or methods to change the system or the environment
How do you assess the funded project with regard to the integration of different disciplines?

notAvailableChoiceText.text: None of the above categories applies

text.text: Before submitting your BRIDGE Proof of Concept project, were the scientific foundations or the underlying project idea (for Proof of Concept) previously supported by funding from the SNSF or Innosuisse?

hintText.text: Please include funding that supported the research results or knowledge base on which the Proof of Concept idea builds

text.text:
SNSF National Centres of Competence in Research (NCCR)
please provide NCCR number and name

SNSF National Research Programmes (NRP)
please provide the programme number and title of the project
International innovation funding (e.g. EUREKA/Eurostars via Innosuisse, bilateral projects))
SCEER (Swiss Competence Centers of Energy Research)
Which funding instruments supported the scientific foundations or project idea prior to the BRIDGE Proof of Concept ?

notAvailableChoiceText.text: We did not benefit from any of these instruments

text.text: Did you use the BRIDGE Coaching support (10 hours) during the project?

notAvailableChoiceText.text: We did not benefit from any of these instruments

text.text: How useful was the BRIDGE Coaching (10 hours) for you and your project?

placeholder.text: Bitte geben Sie hier Ihre Antwort ein.

text.text: In which areas was the BRIDGE Coaching most useful for you?

hintText.text: (Please describe in your own words, e.g. clarifying or sharpening project goals and priorities, reflecting on implementation options or next steps, early discussion of potential application or exploitation paths, targeted feedback on feasibility, positioning or assumptions. personal sparring, orientation or confidence building, etc.)

notAvailableChoiceText.text: We did not benefit from any of these instruments

text.text: Did you use or are you planning to use any additional coaching or support related to the implementation of the project?
How useful was the Innosuisse Entrepreneurship Training for you in relation to your BRIDGE Proof of Concept project?

placeholder.text: Bitte geben Sie hier Ihre Antwort ein.

text.text: In which areas was the Innosuisse Entrepreneurship Training most useful for you?

hintText.text: (Please describe in your own words, e.g. clarifying or sharpening project goals and priorities, reflecting on implementation options or next steps, early discussion of potential application or exploitation paths, targeted feedback on feasibility, positioning or assumptions. personal sparring, orientation or confidence building, etc.)

text.text:
Start-ups and spin-offs
A start-up or spin-off has been established (legal entity)
A start-up or spin-off is in preparation or planned

Non-profit initiatives
A non-profit organisation / NGO has been established
A non-profit organisation / NGO is in preparation or planned

Licensing / transfer
Licensing or transfer of results to a company or organisation has been completed
Licensing or transfer of results is planned or under negotiation

Collaboration with partners
Further development with an implementation partner is ongoing (cooperation, employment)
Further development with an implementation partner is planned (cooperation, employment)
Project continues mainly in research and development (cooperation, further employment)

Other
Project has been completed but not further implemented: overall feasibility not confirmed (technical, business, organisational)
Which status best describes your BRIDGE Proof of Concept-funded project at the end of the funding?

notAvailableChoiceText.text: We have aborted the project and won't pursue it further

text.text: No financing / financing is not secured at all
and in a longer perspective (2 to 5 years)
To what extent is the financing of your project secured?

Research-to-Application and Implementation Pathways 
Unclear pathway to application or implementation
Unclear pathway to application or implementation
Intended start-up pathway not realistic or not suitable
No suitable implementation (e.g. industry, public sector)

Scientific, Conceptual or Technical Challenges 
Scientific results not sufficiently promising
Technical or conceptional feasibility too low
Scientific, methodological issues or data-related challenge

Personal or Career Related Factors 
Missing career opportunity outside of BRIDGE Proof of Concept
Lack of time or personal capacity
Shift in personal or other priorities

Institutional or Resources-related Constraints 
Lack of staff or relevant expertise

Market or Stakeholder-related Challenges 
Low or unclear market potential or societal demand
Collaboration challenges with partners or stakeholders

Intellectual Property and Legal Aspects 
Unclear ownership or access to intellectual property
Negotiation with host institution about intellectual property rights
Limited support or clarity regarding IP strategy at the Proof of Concept stage
In which areas did you face the most significant barriers obstacles during the project or in the follow-up phase after the end of the project?

notAvailableChoiceText.text: We have aborted the project and won't pursue it further

text.text: Unclear pathway to application or implementation
Unclear pathway to application or implementation
Intended start-up pathway not realistic or not suitable
No suitable implementation (e.g. industry, public sector)
Technical or conceptional feasibility too low
Scientific, methodological issues or data-related challenge
Missing career opportunity outside of BRIDGE Proof of Concept
Lack of time or personal capacity
Shift in personal or other priorities
Lack of staff or relevant expertise
Low or unclear market potential or societal demand
Collaboration challenges with partners or stakeholders
Unclear ownership or access to intellectual property
Negotiation with host institution about intellectual property rights
Limited support or clarity regarding IP strategy at the Proof of Concept stage
Which of the selected obstacles is the main or most decisive one?

notAvailableChoiceText.text: We have aborted the project and won't pursue it further

text.text:
Early concept phase
BRL 1 – Basic hypotheses
Initial hypotheses regarding a possible business, implementation or societal impact concept.

BRL 2 – First business model or concept described
First description of a business, implementation or societal impact concept. Initial understanding of target groups, needs or problem context.

Business model and concept development phase 
BRL 3 – Development of business model or concept
Draft business model or draft implementation / impact logic.
Market potential and/or societal relevance and stakeholder landscape described.

BRL 4 – First validated business model or concept
First structured business model or implementation and impact concept. Initial projections of economic viability, market potential and/or societal relevance.
Initial assumptions on feasibility, relevance and potential effects.

Validation phase 
BRL 5 – Business model or concept testing
Testing of the business model or of implementation pathways, user acceptance or societal relevance. Key assumptions validated with external stakeholders or; where applicable, first revenue model and initial competitive positioning.

BRL 6 – Advanced business model or concept validation
Business model or implementation / impact concept largely validated.
Pricing or cost assumptions verified with customers, users or implementing actors, where applicable Product-market fit and finetuning

BRL 7 – Demonstrated applicability and relevance
Product-market fit or solution/context fit demonstrated.
Clear value proposition for customers or beneficiaries and implementing actors.

BRL 8 – Business model or concept finetuned
Business model or broader implementation readiness / impact model refined.
Evidence that the approach is robust and transferable to broader contexts.

Scaling and broader implementation 
BRL 9 – Scaling and implementation readiness
Business scaling with recurring revenues or readiness for larger-scale implementation, institutional embedding or policy uptake.
Which Business Readiness Level (BRL) did your project have at the beginning of the BRIDGE Proof of Concept funding?

hintText.text: Including non-commercial and societal implementation readiness

text.text:
Basic hypotheses
BRL 1 - Hypothesizing on possible business concept
BRL 2 - First business concept described. Identified overall market & some competitors.

Development of business model
BRL 3 - Draft of business model. Described market potential & competitive overview.
BRL 4 - First version of business model, first projections of economic viability & market potential
BRL 5 - Business model testing, first revenue model, competitive position verified im market
BRL 6 - Full business model including pricing verified on customers

Product market fit / finetuning
BRL 7 - Product/market fit demonstrated. Attractive revenue/cost projections.
BRL 8 - Business model is finetuned. Sales & metrics show business model holds and can scale

Business scaling
BRL 9 - Business model finalised. Business scaling with recurring revenues
Which Business Readiness Level (BRL) best describes the status of your project at the end of the BRIDGE Proof of Concept funding?

hintText.text: Including non-commercial and societal implementation readiness

text.text: The project results are not yet sufficiently advanced to decide on a concrete application or implementation path (e.g. start-up, implementation in an existing organisation, or via implementation partners)

The feasibility of the project goals has been examined and concrete implementation steps are identifiable (e.g. start-up formation, licensing, market or societal implementation within an existing organisation, or collaboration with implementation partners).
Conclusive results make it possible to take concrete and further implementation steps.

The project or the innovation is currently in the implementation and introduction phase, either on the market or in a societal / institutional context (e.g. through a start-up, within an existing organisation, or together with implementation partners)
The project/the innovation has been successfully implemented and already generates revenues and/or demonstrates measurable societal benefits or strengthens organisational performance.
The project will not be continued or implemented.
How do you assess at the end of the project the achieved goal of commercial utilisation of the project results and the further implementation on the market?
Not relevant for my BRIDGE Proof of Concept project

Concrete outputs and validation
Prototype, demonstrator or Minimum Viable Product developed (incl. user perspective)
Business feasibility or implementation pathways clarified

Implementation and exploitation
Market, user or societal demand verified
Preparation for implementation (e.g. start-up, licensing, organisation)
Establishment or strengthening of cooperation with potential implementation partners
Licensing or sale of results to a company or organisation

Intellectual property and funding
Securing intellectual property / filing a patent or similar protection (licences)

Societal and other impacts
Contribution to a societal, environmental or technological challenge
Other results or impacts achieved (please specify)
To what extent have the following outcomes been achieved by the end of your BRIDGE Proof of Concept project?
not at all – only possible because of BRIDGE
very likely – would have happened anyway
How likely is it that the above-mentioned outcomes would have been achieved without BRIDGE funding?

How likely is it that your innovation will achieve implementation on the market and/or in society in the medium to long term (e.g. through sales, licensing, integration into an organisation, continued use or long-term application)?
Impact of the BRIDGE support
No, I would not have carried out the project or taken steps towards practical implementation.
Yes, but likely to a much lesser extent.
Yes, but likely to a slightly lesser extent.
Yes, most likely to more or less the same extent.
Would you have carried out the project or taken comparable steps towards practical implementation without BRIDGE Proof of Concept funding?
Essential (the implementation would not have occurred without BRIDGE funding)
Decision for founding a start-up or to pursue an implementation pathway
Timing or acceleration of the founding or implementation process
Quality of the start-up or implementation setup
To what extent did the BRIDGE Proof of Concept funding contribute to the implementation of your innovative idea?

hintText.text: e.g. through a start-up, within an existing organisation, or in a non-commercial, public sector or NGO context

text.text: In-licensing (rights to use, develop, or commercialize intellectual property assets that are owned by another entity)
Out-licensing (granting another entity the rights to use, develop, or commercialize its own intellectual property assets)
What kind of intellectual property rights protection is being realised and planned?
Basic company structures set up (e.g. roles, responsibilities, processes)
Legal entity registered or preparations underway

Market & Business
Initial contacts established with potential customers or pilot partners
Minimum viable product (MVP developed or tested
First customers acquired and / or renvenues achieved

Funding & Strategy
Initial funding plan or financing options mapped out
What is the current development status of your organisation or implementation setup with regard to the following elements?
Before the start of the BRIDGE PoC project
Shortly after the start of the project
When did or will the foundation of a start-up related to your BRIDGE Proof of Concept project take place?
How many employees (FTE) did your company have at the end of [previous year] / currently (full-time equivalents, FTE)?
Yes, but without a successful outcome so far
No, we are pursuing a bootstrapping strategy (financing exclusively through internal resources and revenues; no external equity financing planned)
Since the founding of your start-up, have you undertaken concrete efforts to raise risk capital (dilutive funding)?

hintText.text: By risk capital we mean additional equity financing to support the founding and development phase of a start-up. Investors may include, for example, business angels, venture capitalists, corporate or strategic investors, or FFF (family, friends and fools)

text.text: Which type(s) of investors provided the financing or were actively approached?
Have you raised other funds (non-dilutive) at home or abroad (since the start-up was established)?

Development of knowledge and understanding
(e.g. scientific, technical, entrepreneurial or application-related knowledge)

Concrete career development
(e.g. new career direction, transition to another sector, strengthened professional role)
To what extent did the BRIDGE Proof of Concept project contribute to your knowledge development and career development?
Gaining experience in project management and leadership
Increasing visibility or reputation within the research community
Enhancing confidence to take risks or pursue new ideas
In which areas did the BRIDGE PoC funding contribute most to your career development?
Accept the position – advancing my research career is the priority
Negotiate to continue the innovation work part-time or in parallel
Decline the offer – bringing this innovation to application is too important
Accept, but plan to return to the innovation later

Imagine you received an attractive job offer from a prestigious research institution or company, but accepting it would mean discontinuing your work on commercializing or practically implementing your BRIDGE innovation. What would you do?

hintText.text: Please select the option that best reflects your likely decision

text.text: Entrepreneurial Mindset and Behaviour
No, customers or users were not actively involved

Exporation and early feedback 
Interviews, surveys or exploratory feedback
Pilot projects or test phases with users, customers or beneficiaries

Market-oriented or contextual validation (where applicable) 
Letters of Intent (LoI) or Memoranda of Understanding (MoU)
Testing willingness to pay or willingness to adopt
Initial sales, pre-orders or comparable commitments
Were customers or users actively involved in the development within your BRIDGE Proof of Concept project?

hintText.text:
This may include customers, users, beneficiaries, public authorities or other relevant stakeholders, depending on the implementation context.
Multiple answers possible.

text.text: Experimenting with ideas and validating assumptions
Dealing with uncertainty, setbacks and learning from failure

Bringing innovation ideas into practice
(e.g. engaging users, beneficiaries, partners or markets)
To what extent did the BRIDGE Proof of Concept funding support you in the following aspects?
Essential (would not have developed without funding)
Customer, user or beneficiary discovery (problem–solution fit)
Developing and testing ideas in practice

Building networks and partnerships relevant for implementation
(e.g. companies, public sector, NGOs or other organisations)
Leading and taking responsibility for implementation
Designing value propositions and implementation or business models

Go-to-market or implementation basics
(e.g. positioning, channels, pricing, cost recovery or adoption tests)

Understanding and preparing financing options for further development
(e.g. private, public or blended financing)
To what extent did the BRIDGE Proof of Concept funding strengthen your entrepreneurial and innovation-related competencies?
Overall, how successful do you consider your BRIDGE Proof of Concept project to have been in achieving its intended objectives?
Overall, how satisfied are you with the BRIDGE Proof of Concept funding and support?
Support from the university/research institution (e.g., Research Office, Technology Transfer Office, etc.)
Specifically, how satisfied are you with the support you received during the project?

Looking back at your participation in the BRIDGE Proof of Concept programme:
What worked particulary well?

placeholder.text: Bitte geben Sie hier Ihre Antwort ein.

text.text: Where do you see room for improvement?

surveyEndText.text: Thank you very much for your participation. Your responses have been sent.
